Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: A Topological Analysis of Uncertainly Representation in the Brain

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Characterizing how brain regions activate, collaborate, and interact in cognition empowers us with advanced approaches to help humans make the right decisions on high stress jobs, prevent drug abuse, and treat neurological disorders. This project will study cognitive control in terms of the uncertainty representation, namely, how brains execute the same cognitive task with different levels of uncertainty. Based on theory and algorithms in topology data analysis, the project will analyze brain functional MRI images using novel topological descriptors, which directly model global interactions between brain regions in a principled manner. These descriptors will be used in novel learning models to discover brain activity patterns that are crucial for uncertainty representation. The outcome of the project will include (1) new knowledge in uncertainty representation, e.g., fine-scale activity patterns and interactions between brain regions correlated to the uncertainty level; (2) new topological analysis tools for brain imaging study. This project will bring research and educational opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students from both computer science and neuroscience. The PIs will also mentor students from underrepresented groups and high school students through the CUNY College Now program.

This project will create new computational topology algorithms to extract rich information from the intrinsic structure of data. Novel machine learning methods will be created in order to leverage the topological structures for not only prediction, but also knowledge discovery. A novel interactive data exploration platform based on topological features will be developed for brain imaging study. These techniques and software will be validated on task-evoked fMRI data to produce quantitative assessments of accuracy and to characterize advantages and limitations of these approaches. Domain experts will validate the quality of the approach in validating scientific hypotheses and data exploration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project endeavors to unify advanced mathematical tools and machine learning methods for better understanding of human brain functionality. Through the project, we have developed novel methodology and applied them to the analysis of brain imaging data. We use advanced topological tools such as persistent homology and discrete Morse theory. We used advanced learning methods such as group sparsity, graph neural networks, CNN, etc. We used the developed methods to investigate how human brain executes cognitive tasks with different uncertainty conditions, sensory modalities, and visual attention mechanisms. The outcome includes not only advanced data analysis methodology, but also deeper insights into brain functionality.

In terms of methodology, we found that by leveraging connectivity and topological information in a novel way and combining them with deep learning methods, we can develop powerful yet interpretable methods for brain image analysis. Our methods utilize advanced topological informant that were not exploited by previous methods. We developed interpretable methods to discover critical brain regions and brain connections.

Beside new analysis methodology, this project also results in new insights into human cognitive control. We have (1) identified a critical brain region to be the information bottleneck for cognitive control over tasks with uncertainty; (2) discovered that brains execute cognitive control tasks independent of the sensory modalities; and (3) different neuron clusters are responsible for different human visual attention modes (covert and overt).

A total of 10 papers have been published over the course of the project, in different domains including topological data analysis, machine learning, medical image analysis, and neuroscience. The results were disseminated to the public through publications and shared software. PIs and graduate students have attended scientific conferences and present the research results.

Several phd student and one postdoc were trained during the course of this project. One female student graduated with PhD degree and started her data scientist career. One female postdoc gained rich research experience through the project and will continue with her academic career path.
